perturbation.original_text: The Joint Venture shall commence on the 1st of March, 2003, and shall be effective until February 28, 2004 unless extended by written agreement of the Joint Venturers not less than thirty (30) days prior to scheduled termination.
perturbation.changed_text: The Joint Venture shall commence on the 1st of March, 2003, and shall be effective until February 28, 2004 unless extended by written agreement of the Joint Venturers not less than ten (10) days prior to scheduled termination.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the notification period for extension to 10 days could be considered unreasonable, especially in complex ventures. This could be argued as conflicting with the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing present in Pennsylvania contract law, where a more reasonable timeframe might be expected to allow for proper deliberation and negotiation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing under Pennsylvania contract law.

perturbation.original_text: On any termination of the Joint Venture, its debt shall be paid or provided for in a manner satisfactory to the Joint Venturers.
perturbation.changed_text: On any termination of the Joint Venture, its debt shall be addressed at the discretion of the managing venturer.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the requirement for mutual agreement on debt repayment upon termination. Under Pennsylvania law, all venturers must share in the responsibilities for debts and liabilities. Deferring responsibility to a 'managing venturer' without a defined process for satisfaction of debts introduces ambiguity and could violate the principles of equal responsibility in joint ventures, and fiduciary duties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General partnership and joint venture law regarding the responsibility for debts and liabilities in Pennsylvania.

perturbation.original_text: Any notice which a Joint Venturer shall have occasion to give to the other Joint Venturer shall be deemed sufficient notice for all purposes as to its contents if given in writing, hand delivered, by fax, or prepaid mail, to the address of such Joint Venturer as set out below his signature.
perturbation.changed_text: Any notice which a Joint Venturer shall have occasion to give to the other Joint Venturer shall be deemed sufficient notice if sent via social media, to the address of such Joint Venturer as set out below his signature.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing standard notification methods (hand delivery, fax, prepaid mail) with social media can be problematic. Under Pennsylvania law, while electronic communication is generally accepted, the method must be reasonable and reliable, especially for important legal notices. Using social media without specifying a platform, secure communication, or confirmation of receipt could be deemed insufficient, particularly for crucial notifications related to breach, termination, or financial matters. This does not constitute a resonable form of legal notification.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania Uniform Electronic Transactions Act (UETA) regarding reasonable and reliable methods for electronic communication of legal notices.
